message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, including the bluish-brown sclerae and the calcification of intervertebral discs, suggest alkaptonuria, a rare genetic disorder caused by impaired metabolism of tyrosine. It causes accumulation of homogentisic acid, leading to ochronosis and joint destruction. The dark brown stains around the armpits are due to the oxidation of homogentisic acid in sweat.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest alkaptonuria, which is caused by the impaired metabolism of tyrosine. Dark brown stains around the armpits (ochronosis), bluish-brown sclerae, and calcification of lumbar intervertebral discs are all hallmarks of alkaptonuria. The other options are not associated with these symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and findings suggest the patient suffers from alkaptonuria, which is caused by impaired metabolism of tyrosine. The brown stains around the armpits are likely to be due to the accumulation of homogentisic acid in the sweat glands.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and examination findings suggest a diagnosis of alkaptonuria, which is caused by impaired metabolism of tyrosine. The dark brown stains on the patient's shirt are likely due to the buildup of homogentisic acid, a metabolite of tyrosine in alkaptonuria.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The combination of symptoms and findings suggests ankylosing spondylitis, which is associated with HLA-B27 and impaired metabolism of tyrosine. Homocysteine metabolism is associated with hyperhomocysteinemia, while impaired metabolism of tryptophan is associated with niacin deficiency. Ornithine metabolism is associated with ornithine transcarbamylase deficiency, which presents with hyperammonemia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination findings point to Alkaptonuria, which is caused by impaired metabolism of tyrosine. The dark brown stains around the armpits are due to accumulation of homogentisic acid, the urine of these patients turns black on standing. X-rays showing calcification of lumbar intervertebral discs and joint dysfunction also support the diagnosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and findings suggest alkaptonuria, a rare genetic disorder caused by impaired metabolism of tyrosine. This results in accumulation of homogentisic acid, which is excreted in urine and causes brownish-black staining upon prolonged exposure to air. The calcification of intervertebral discs is also a characteristic feature of alkaptonuria. Tryptophan metabolism is associated with niacin deficiency and ornithine metabolism is associated with urea cycle disorders, but neither of these conditions match the patient's presentation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination findings are characteristic of alkaptonuria, which is caused by impaired metabolism of tyrosine. This results in the buildup of homogentisic acid, which causes the discoloration of sclerae and urine and the calcification of intervertebral discs. None of the other options are associated with these symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms, including the bluish-brown sclerae and thickened ear, suggest Alkaptonuria, a metabolic disorder caused by impaired metabolism of tyrosine. Homocysteine is associated with cardiovascular disease and impaired metabolism of tryptophan can lead to serotonin deficiency, but neither match the patient's symptoms. Ornithine is involved in the urea cycle and not related to the patient's condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination findings suggest the patient has ankylosing spondylitis, which is associated with HLA-B27 gene and impaired metabolism of amino acid tyrosine. None of the other options are associated with ankylosing spondylitis. The dark brown stains around the armpits are likely due to excessive sweating (hyperhidrosis) commonly seen in ankylosing spondylitis.
